Idiom (Láadan): Bíi hal mehal neth sho neme
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To speak kindly when one is secretly angry; to hide true feelings behind politeness.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To pretend to be kind while being upset.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Láadan proverb teaching emotional honesty; often used among elders in village councils.
First Example Sentence: Bíi hal mehal neth sho neme wa, be ril neth le.
Second Example Sentence: Béé hal le wa neth sho neme, neme neth le ril.
Third Example Sentence: Báa hal le mehal sho neme, wa neth ril le?
